To explore toxic mechanisms of nano-ZnO on marine microalgae, algal growth inhibition test was carried out, and total Zn in the cell and total dissolved Zn in f/2 medium were determined. It was found that nanoZnO was more toxic than bulk-ZnO on marine microalgae Skeletonema costatum. No matter under nanoZnO or bulk-ZnO treatment, accumulation of intracellular Zn had a good linear correlation with growth inhibition ratio (IR). The total Zn content in the cell of microalgae was the dominant toxic mechanism of ZnO. Intracellular total Zn could be an indispensable parameter to indicate the toxic effects of nano-
ano-ZnO oxicity test ntracellular total Zn keletonema costatum
ZnO. Higher intracellular total Zn under nano-ZnO treatment than bulk-ZnO resulted in more toxicity of nano-ZnO on microalgae. Compared with Zn2+ released by nano-ZnO into medium, lipid peroxidation (MDA level) injury, aggregation of nano-ZnO and transmembrane process of nano-ZnO also contributed to toxicity of nano-ZnO on Skeletonema costatum. The accumulation of intracellular Zn provides a new insight into toxic mechanisms of nano-ZnO.

. Introduction
Nanomaterials due to their nanoscale have some excellent haracteristics such as high reactivity, optical property and electroagnetic property (Chen and Mao, 2007; Colvin, 2003). In recent ears, some excellent nanomaterials have already moved rapidly rom the laboratory to large scale industry. Among them, nanoiO2 is the most worldwide production that is up to approximately 0000 t/year and nano-ZnO is also produced between 100 and 000 t/year in the world (Piccinno et al., 2012). Especially, nanonO has rich applications in sunscreen, plastics, rubber, lubricants, igments, food additives, batteries and fire retardants, etc (Ma et al., 013). The extensive production and use of nano-ZnO increase the otential for its release to the environment. With high reactivity nd special size, nano-ZnO has become an emerging contaminant hich can cause toxic effects to organisms (Oberdörster et al., 2005; harifi et al., 2012; Wiesner et al., 2006). 70% of the amount of nano-ZnO were used in production of unscreen (Piccinno et al., 2012), and about 25% of the amount f sunscreen including materials such as nano-ZnO were washed ff during bathing and swimming (Danovaro et al., 2008). Coastal ystems are likely to be the ultimate sink for many nanomate-

rials, deliberately or purposely discharged into the environment (Klaine et al., 2008). Toxic effects of nanomaterials to marine organisms have been reported by several studies (D’Agata et al., 2014; Galloway et al., 2010; Wong et al., 2010). Microalgae as model organisms are often used in marine eco-toxicological tests for their important implications to marine ecosystem. Toxic effects of nanomaterials on microalgae get more and more attention by many scholars (Bouldin et al., 2008; Miller et al., 2010; Röhder et al., 2014).
Although many studies focused on toxic effects caused by nanoZnO on microalgae at present (Aravantinou et al., 2015; Neale et al., 2015; Tang et al., 2015), toxic mechanism of nano-ZnO on microalgae is still ambiguous. The Zn2+ released by nano-ZnO is always a bone of contention. Aruoja et al. (2009) thought the toxicity of nano-ZnO on Pseudokirchneriella subcapitata in the low concentration range was attributed solely to solubilized Zn2+. Miao et al. (2010) found that ZnO-engineered (20 nm) toxicity on the marine diatom Thalassiosira pseudonana could be solely explained by Zn2+ released. Miller et al. (2010) also considered that free Zn2+ was the major contribution to toxicity of nano-ZnO on marine phytoplankton. However, some studies showed that released Zn2+ could not explain toxicity of nano-ZnO completely. Manzo et al. (2013) found primary size of nano-ZnO affected its overall toxicity and toxic effects of nano-ZnO could not be explained only by the free zinc ion action. Ji et al. (2011) also thought dissolved Zn2+ from nano-ZnO was not the dominant mechanism for the algal growth inhibition. Most studies focused on Zn2+ released by nano-ZnO, but

In this study, toxic comparison between nano-ZnO and bulknO on a marine diatom Skeletonema costatum through algal growth
nhibition tests was carried out. Determined total Zn in the cell nd total dissolved Zn in f/2 medium was used to explore the ontribution to toxic effects of nano-ZnO based on accumulation f intracellular Zn. Malondialdehyde (MDA) level was also deterined to try to explain more accumulation of Zn in the cell under ano-ZnO treatment. Meanwhile, SEM images of nano-ZnO and ulk-ZnO in f/2 medium revealed agglomeration of nanoparticles nd TEM images of transmembrane nano-ZnO particles showed he interaction between nano-ZnO and algae. To the best of our nowledge, this is the first time to study the relationship between ntracellular total Zn of marine microalgae and toxicity of nanonO. Accumulation of intracellular Zn may provide a new insight nto toxic mechanisms of nano-ZnO on microalgae.
. Materials and methods
.1. Chemicals
Nano-ZnO, dry powders (CAS:1314-13-2, 99.8% metals basis, 0 ± 10 nm) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation, hina. Bulk-ZnO, dry powders (CAS:1314-13-2, 99.9% purity, 1 m) ere purchased from Shanghai ST-Nano Science & Technology Co., TD, China.
.2. Organisms
The algal strain Skeletonema costatum (Bacillariophyta) was btained from the Algal Center of Key Laboratory of Marine Chem-
stry Theory and Technology, Ocean University of China. The icroalgae was cultivated in f/2 medium (Guillard and Ryther, 962) made with sterile seawater (filtered by 0.45 m membrane) rom Qingdao, China. The microalgae was cultivated in 5 L Erlen-
eyer flask at 20 ± 1 ◦C under cool continuous white fluorescent ights (4000 lx) with a 12-h light/dark cycle, and shaken twice a ay to prevent the sedimentation of algae. The incubation was asted 5–7 days until log phase growth prevailed. Cell density was easured by hemacytometer under inverted microscope (Leica, M4000B) with 400 magnification times.
.3. Preparation of ZnO suspensions
Stock solution of both nano-ZnO and bulk-ZnO were prepared hrough dispersing dry ZnO powders into milli-Q water to the nal concentration of 100 mg/L. The well-dispersed stock solution hrough shaking and sonicating could keep in storage for a week t room temperature. The stock solution was diluted with milli-Q ater (50, 30, 10 and 5 mg/L), and then ultrasound bathed 30 min t 50 W for dispersion before the toxicity assay.
.4. Algal growth inhibition test
All tests in the study complied with OECD (Organization for Ecoomic Cooperation and Development) Guidelines 201. Glassware as acid-soaked, cleaned with milli-Q water, and then autoclaved efore test. 100 mL pre-cultured algal cells in log phase growth ere transferred into 250 mL Erlenmeyer flask, then both nano-ZnO nd bulk-ZnO suspensions (10 mL) under different concentrations ere added into the test flask in triplicate respectively. The final oncentrations of ZnO in algal growth inhibition tests were 0, 0.5, , 3, 5 and 10 mg/L (0, 6.14, 12.3, 36.9, 61.4 and 123 mol/L) for easy

comparison on toxic effect between two kinds of ZnO. The test flasks were randomly placed in the growth incubator for 4 days under the condition in accordance with pre-cultured condition. The cell density was counted every 24 h and the 4 days growth curve was available.
2.5. Determination of total Zn in the cell and total dissolved Zn in f/2 medium
After 96 h algal growth inhibition test, 50 mL microalgae medium under different ZnO concentrations were centrifuged at 3000 rpm for 10 min. Removed supernatant liquid and added 10 mL 0.1 mol phosphate buffer (pH = 7.4) into the centrifuge tube, the samples were centrifuged at 3000 rpm for 10 min again. The above procedure was repeated, but 0.1 mol phosphate buffer (pH = 7.4) was changed to 3 mmol HNO3, 0.1 mol phosphate buffer (pH = 7.4) and 3 mmol Na2-EDTA in turn. These processes could remove ZnO and Zn2+ adsorbed on the cell surface (Piovár et al., 2011). After removing supernatant liquid, algal cells at the bottom of centrifuge tube were digested in 3 mL 65% HNO3 and 1 mL 30% H2O2 (2:1, v/v) for 48 h and then the volume was diluted to 10 mL with milli-Q water for determination. Algal cells were proved to be unbroken under microscope before digested to ensure that the measured Zn was intracellular.
As preparation of ZnO suspensions, dry ZnO powders were dispersed into f/2 medium to the final concentration of 100 mg/L (in triplicate). ZnO in f/2 medium through shaking and sonicating was well-dispersed. 100 mg/L well-dispersed suspensions of nano-ZnO and bulk-ZnO in f/2 medium were observed with scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi S-4800 cold field-emission) to compare aggregation degree between them. Samples dried under nitrogen were fixed on the conductive adhesive and coated with a thin layer of gold under vacuum conditions. 10 mL well-dispersed suspensions in f/2 medium was centrifuged at 4000 rpm for 20 min. 5 mL supernatant liquid was taken into a volumetric flask with 5% HNO3 to a final volume of 10 mL for total dissolved Zn determination.
Analysis of total Zn accumulation in the cell and total dissolved Zn in f/2 medium was performed using an Inductively Coupled Plasma-Atomic Emission Spectrometry (Thermo Fisher Scientific, ICAP-6300). Three replicates for each treatment in each set were analyzed.
2.6. Sample preparation for TEM
Dry nano-ZnO powders were well dispersed in alcohol and observed with transmission electron microscope (TEM, Hitachi H7650). After 24 h exposure under 10 mg/L ZnO treatment, algal cells were collected by centrifugation (3000 rpm, 10 min), and cells were fixed by 2.5% glutaraldehyde at 4 ◦C overnight. The samples were then washed with 0.1 mol phosphate buffer solution (PBS, pH 7.4) by centrifugation (3000 rpm, 10 min) three times. Algal cells were fixed by 1% osmium tetroxide at 4 ◦C for 1 h, and then were washed with 0.1 mol PBS (pH 7.4) by centrifugation (3000 rpm, 10 min) three times. Samples were dehydrated successively through a series of acetone solutions of 30%, 50%, 70%, 80%, 90%, 95% and 100% for 20 min. After dehydration, samples were fixed with resin and made into slice for final observation.
2.7. Oxidative level
Malondialdehyde (MDA) level under 10 mg/L ZnO concentration at 24 h and 96 h was determined using a diagnostic reagent kit (Chen et al., 2015) (Nanjing Jiancheng Bioengineering Institute, Nanjing, China).

Data were expressed as average ± standard eviation in the study. Growth inhibition ratio (IR) was calcuated as: IR(%) = (1 − T/C) × 100%, where T and C were cell density n experimental group and control group respectively. 50% effecive concentration (EC50) value was calculated by software SPSS 9 with 95% confidence interval.
. Results and discussion
.1. Algal growth inhibition tests
For toxic comparison between nano-ZnO and bulk-ZnO, growth urve of microalgae Skeletonema costatum under different conentrations of ZnO within 96 h was developed according to algal rowth inhibition tests (Fig. 1). As a practical toxicity parameter, 0% effective concentration, EC50 was also applied in this study Table 1).
The cell density decreased with nano-ZnO concentration ncreasing in every time (Fig. 1A). Even under treatment of 0.5 mg/L ano-ZnO concentration, the cell density had a significant decrease p < 0.05) compared with control at 72 h and 96 h. When nano-ZnO oncentration was higher than 1 mg/L (including 1 mg/L), all cell ensity significantly decreased (p < 0.05) in every time. Nano-ZnO reatment completely inhibited the growth of microalgae under 5 nd 10 mg/L concentrations. The most obvious inhibitory effects of ano-ZnO appeared at 96 h, at which the difference of cell density etween control and treatments was maximum. The growth inhiition of bulk-ZnO on microalgae was clearly inferior to nano-ZnO Fig. 1B). The cell density began to decrease significantly (p < 0.05) nly at 96 h under 1 mg/L bulk-ZnO concentration. density significantly decreased (p < 0.05) comparing with control in every time. The microalgae slowly grew under 5 and 10 mg/L concentrations of bulk-ZnO, while the microalgae completely stopped growing under the same concentration of nano-ZnO. The most obvious inhibitory effects of bulk-ZnO also appeared at 96 h which was the same as that of nano-ZnO. Compared with control, the difference of cell density was 209 × 104 cell/mL under treatment of 10 mg/L nano-ZnO concentration at 96 h, however, the difference under treatment of 10 mg/L bulk-ZnO was just 179 × 104 cell/mL. Inhibitory effects on algal growth under nano-ZnO treatment were significant stronger (independent sample t-test, p < 0.05) than that of bulk-ZnO.
Toxicity of ZnO on microalgae was accumulated with time since the value of EC50 for both nano-ZnO and bulk-ZnO reduced with time (Table 1). The strongest toxic effect appeared at 96 h in this study. The value of 96 h-EC50 was 3.6 and 5.5 mg/L under nanoZnO and bulk-ZnO treatment, respectively. EC50 of nano-ZnO at 96 h was nearly half of that at 24 h. EC50 of nano-ZnO was lower than bulk-ZnO in every time meant the overall toxicity of nanoZnO was higher than bulk-ZnO. Many reasons were reported for causing different toxicity effects in tests, such as species of microalgae, characteristic of ZnO and culture conditions (Aravantinou et al., 2015; Peng et al., 2011). Wong and Leung (2014) studied toxicity of nano-ZnO (size, 20 nm) to five marine organisms in which EC50 of nano-ZnO on microalgae S. costatum and T. pseudonana was 2.36 (2.11–2.64) and 4.56 (4.06–5.11) mg/L at 96 h. Aravantinou et al. (2015) found EC50 of nano-ZnO on microalgae D. tertiolecta was only 1.50 (NG) mg/L at 96 h, meanwhile Manzo et al. (2013) got EC50 of nano-ZnO on the same microalgae was 2.42 (0.97–2.87) mg/L. The value of EC50 in this study was the same order of magnitude with those previous studies. To different size of ZnO, ZnO (nanoscale) which had smaller size was more toxic than large size (micron scale) (Ji et al., 2011; Manzo et al., 2013).
In a word, both nano-ZnO and bulk-ZnO inhibited the growth of S. costatum and the most obvious inhibitory effects of ZnO appeared at 96 h. Nano-ZnO was more toxic than bulk-ZnO on microalgae.
3.2. Total Zn in the cell and total dissolved Zn in f/2 medium

Total dissolved Zn under bulk-ZnO treatment was less than that of nano-ZnO before 24 h, however, total dissolved Zn under nano-ZnO and bulk-ZnO treatment did not have a significant difference after 24 h (independent sample t-test, p > 0.05). It was found a linear relationship between intracellular total Zn and IR for both nano-ZnO and bulk-ZnO (Fig. 3). The linear under nano-ZnO treatment (Fig. 3A) had the similar slope and intercept with linear under bulk-ZnO treatment (Fig. 3B), which indicated intracellular total Zn could be used to explain IR in a similar pathway for both nano-ZnO and bulk-ZnO. The good linear correlation confirmed that intracellular total Zn was the dominant reason for algal growth inhibition. It was also found linear relationships between difference value of intracellular total Zn and difference value of IR (Fig. 4), which had a potential to explain difference of toxicity between nano-ZnO and bulk-ZnO. The difference value of IR increased rapidly with difference value of intracellular total Zn increasing when ZnO concentration was less than 1 mg/L and increased slowly when ZnO concentration was more than 3 mg/L. It was found the same results in Fig. 2. In brief, compared to Zn2+ released in the medium, intracellular total Zn was a dominant factor to explain the toxic mechanism of nano-ZnO.
3.3. Sources of intracellular total Zn
According to the above results, the total Zn content in the cell of microalgae was the dominant toxic mechanism of ZnO. Higher intracellular total Zn under nano-ZnO treatment than bulk-ZnO resulted in more toxicity of nano-ZnO on microalgae. If extra intracellular total Zn was a parameter relating to the more toxicity of nano-ZnO, it was important to find the sources of extra intracellular total Zn in nano-ZnO suspension. The extent of lipid peroxidation (MDA level) often indicated the degree of oxidation to biofilm. If cell membrane was oxidized, its permeability and fluidity was changed which may increase transmembrane ability of Zn2+. In this study, the MDA level induced by nano-ZnO in microalgae significantly increased (p < 0.05) under 10 mg/L concentration at 96 h and the value was 1.8 times compared with control. At the same time, the MDA level induced by bulk-ZnO did not have obvious increase at 24 h and 96 h (Fig. 5). Bhuvaneshwari et al. (2015) also found reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation were significantly enhanced
icity of nano-ZnO on Scenedesmus obliquus under different light conditions. Lipid peroxidation was a potential reason for increasing intracellular total Zn.

4. Conclusion
This study showed that nano-ZnO caused more powerful inhibitory effects on microalgal growth than bulk-ZnO. IR increased with time and to the maximum at 96 h under both kinds ZnO treatment. The value of 96 h-EC50 was 3.6 and 5.5 mg/L under nano-ZnO and bulk-ZnO treatment, respectively. Nano-ZnO was more toxicity than bulk-ZnO on marine microalgae Skeletonema costatum. No matter under nano-ZnO or bulk-ZnO treatment, accumulation of intracellular Zn had a good linear correlation with IR. The total Zn content in the cell of microalgae was the dominant toxic mechanism of ZnO. Higher intracellular total Zn under nano-ZnO treatment than bulk-ZnO resulted in more toxicity of nano-ZnO on microalgae. Intracellular total Zn could be a dominant factor to explain the toxic mechanism of nano-ZnO. Compared with Zn2+ released by nano-ZnO into medium, lipid peroxidation (MDA level) injury, aggregation of nano-ZnO and transmembrane process of nano-ZnO also contributed to toxicity. metadata.abstractText: To explore toxic mechanisms of nano-ZnO on marine microalgae, algal growth inhibition test was carried out, and total Zn in the cell and total dissolved Zn in f/2 medium were determined. It was found that nanoZnO was more toxic than bulk-ZnO on marine microalgae Skeletonema costatum. No matter under nanoZnO or bulk-ZnO treatment, accumulation of intracellular Zn had a good linear correlation with growth inhibition ratio (IR).
